awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research Experience for Undergraduates in High Efficiency Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
Information Technology (IT) systems range from small embedded systems such as smartphones to large computer facilities such as data centers. Whether small or large, IT systems proportionately use lots of energy. They also waste a lot, as in shorter battery life or higher data-center operating costs, so improving their efficiency fulfills a critical national need. The objective of this project is to propose solutions to increase energy efficiency in IT  systems by: 1) developing a well-trained student workforce, and 2) proposing new techniques and approaches capable of reducing energy consumption and losses. Students will be introduced to the research area of applying power optimization techniques to IT systems. The target populations are underrepresented students and those from institutions that do not offer PhDs. In addition to academic mentoring by Indiana University Purdue University Indianapolis (IUPUI) faculty, this project includes mentors from industry.

Traditionally, IT curricula have been developed with disciplines that focus on parameters, such as performance and runtime optimization. Little or no attention has been devoted to achieving energy efficiency and consumption thresholds, especially from the software and algorithmic perspectives. This project will provide original experiences and singular opportunities for undergraduate students to work on innovative strategies to reduce energy consumption and losses in IT systems. In addition to the potential change in the career paths of the selected students, this project suggests how the electrical and computer engineering curricula can be impacted to incorporate energy efficiency in both hardware and software curricula.

This project will demonstrate novel methodologies in reducing energy consumption and losses within IT systems, which can be accomplished with a multidisciplinary approach. Topics will range from hardware to software solutions with efficiency as the main figure of merit. Traditionally, Multiple-Voltage Multiple-Frequency (MVMF) has been used to reduce energy consumption in computing systems. This project proposes MVMF2, which not only dynamically changes the computer clock frequency, but also dynamically changes power supply switching frequency for further loss reduction. While MVMF2 is considered a hardware optimization managed by software, the second research topic - a higher efficiency power supply based on a new power converter design - is purely a hardware solution. The third and fourth research topics are software solutions to reduce energy consumption in high memory demand applications and processing big matrix multiplication, respectively. The fifth research topic deals with energy consumption reduction techniques in wireless Internet of Things devices by modeling and optimizing power saving modes, such as reduced power operation, cyclical sleep, among others.

por.por_cntn:
Improving efficiency in Information technology (IT) systems is critical to guarantee battery savings in embedded systems and reduce operating costs in data centers. The objective of this REU program was to propose solutions to increase efficiency in IT-based systems by proposing new techniques and approaches capable of reducing energy consumption and losses implemented by a well-trained student workforce.


A total of 29 students were trained with state-of-the-art techniques and world-class laboratories in the IT and energy processing fields. For instance, It was proposed a wireless power transfer system with a dynamic positioning mechanism that allows power transfer with high efficiency for a large range of relative position between emitting and receiving coils. The system has a self-alignment feature for tracking the optimum angle to maximize power transfer between both coils. Modeling simulation and experimental results have been presented to validate the proposed system. This dynamic wireless power transfer system is suitable for applications that include ground charging station and a superior dock charging system. Another example of specific objective accomplished during this program was a new topology of an isolated DC-DC converter with reduced number of power switches and independent output voltage control. The topology presented reduced the stress on the switches while proportionally increasing the efficiency of the power supply. The modulation technique created for this topology required a microcontroller that can have and independent phase shift for each of its PWM at a fast clock speed. The converter modeling, PWM control strategy, simulation and experimental results have been done by the students in the second cohort.


With the rise of energy consumption, especially in the manufacturing sector, energy management systems are being developed to increase the energy efficiency of smart buildings and factories. These energy management systems are able to derive energy consumption parameters and visualize environmental data collected from a data acquisition platform. Internet of Things (loT) technologies can be used to acquire this data, but will face challenges in industrial settings-lack of cyber secure communication, poor scalability, and minimal back-end functionality are to name a few. Then it was proposed a data acquisition platform for industrial energy management that combats these loT challenges. The implemented platform utilizes the Message Queuing Telemetry Transport (MQTT) protocol to establish fast and simple communication between constrained loT devices. A home automation platform called open Home Automation Bus (openHAB) was utilized as an integration platform due to its balance between functionality and user experience. However, since openHAB does not offer end-to-end payload encryption for MQTT, a method of secure communication to and from openHAB was developed using AES-128 and XChaCha20 algorithms. To improve loT scalability, a method of dynamic sensor configuration was also created, which mitigates open-HAB configuration time. Finally, though many databases were supported, Influx Database (InfluxDB) was integrated alongside openHAB to collect and analyze sensor data. The study concludes that the implemented system provides a data acquisition platform with sensor data storage and secure communication for easy integration and used in buildings or smart factories.


Another study done by the students in this program developed a low cost, user friendly implementation of an IoT sensor node that supports various sensors and their communication protocols including 1-Wire, I2C, SPI, and UART to be used in an energy management systems. Such a goal was accomplished by developing a no-programming configurable sensor node that utilizes the Z-Wave plus wireless communication protocol and Commercial Off The Shelf (COTS) products. This improved functionality and reduced overall system costs. To make the device more user friendly, the authors developed software architecture that configures sensors by reading Dual In-line Package (DIP) switch inputs, which relieved the user of any programming. Through the testing process, the Z-Uno board on the market was found to be the most applicable piece of hardware to implement the architecture. It is proven that the proposed approach can be a viable option for building simple, user-friendly IoT-based no-programming sensor nodes.
The students from all cohorts had the opportunity to work intensively in different laboratories at IUPUI, but also participated in the following major activities: 1) Technical visit to MISO (Midcontinent Independent System Operator), which is an independent, not-for-profit, member-based organization focused on managing the flow of high-voltage electricity and planning the grid of the future; 2) Presentation at TASI’s Labs in the Stutz Building where the students had the opportunity to learn that TASI is a world-class research laboratory that deals primarily with connected and autonomous vehicles and intelligent transportation systems through collaboration and partnership with academics, industry, government, and other organizations; and  3) We also promoted small groups conversations with the faculty members that were aligned with the students’ main interests.
